32299923.review:
I haven't played this game for very long yet, but I'm already in love with it. This is a retro remake done right!

I never played the original version of this game, so I have no nostalgia goggles about how good it was. I bought this game based on the hand-drawn remastered graphics, because the world has too few games that put such effort into their art. The art is drawn with both skill and love, and it shows. Very fluid transitional and incidental animations, and they really give the characters, well, character.

The remastered soundtrack is beautiful so far as well. It was recorded with actual instruments, a rare touch in indie games these days that makes the gaming experience that much richer. Either way, it's cheerful and atmospheric.

The game itself is fun. It feels right for a platformer from 1989. Controls with just the right amount of play in them to force you to plan your play, not just twitch your way through, yet tight enough that you can twitch in a pinch. Difficulty (on normal mode) is challenging, but not unfair. It feels so far like a bit of a Metroidvania style game, with each area I've visited so far teasing towards alternate approaches and secret shortcuts once I've unlocked the right power. You get bumped back to the hub world when you die, which is a little frustrating, but not out of line with how games were made back in the day. No save points for you to crawl your way between — develop the skill and memory to make it through the long haul!

I look forward to my next session with this game. I highly recommend it to platformer fans and fans of good art and music in games, whether or not you're familiar with the game's pixellated origins.

32294344.review:
God, this remake is SO. GOOD. 

I grew up with Wonder Boy 3. I was the Sega kid on the block that had the Master System while everyone else had the NES. Wonder Boy 3, along with part 2, Phantasy Star, and several other Master System games formed my ideas about what good game design is. 

Wonder Boy 3 is still marvelously designed. It's essentially a proto-Metroidvania, where after the introduction you are dropped into a village in the middle of a semi open world. Once you unlock abilities, more areas become available and previous areas will have different routes that lead to secrets. This game rewards experimentation and exploration, especially with the armor and weaponry, which some rarer items have special abilities. 

This is a great game to play in between massive AAA games. The play time will be less than 10 hours and would be a great, refreshing break in between other larger games. 

The art direction is MASTERFUL. The music is great, even though when I was a kid the music always sounded much more "metal". The devs decided to give it a more folky vibe with a lot of acoustic instruments and whatnot. Very nice but I still think I prefer the 8 bit tunes. This is all a personal preference though. 

The physics of the game may seem a bit slippy slidy, but you will get used to it. It's nice for a character to actually feel like there is some weight behind them. Also, the option to be Wonder Girl is super cool too. 

I really applaud these devs for undertaking this remake. If they could now remake part 2 or Monster World, that'd be really amazing!

1989年に発売された
『モンスターワールドII ドラゴンの罠』のリメイク作。
美しいアニメーションと８ビットの世界を切り替えられる。

32293700.review:
Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap is lovingly crafted recreation almost completely faithful the original in gameplay, but with gorgeous hand drawn artwork and a remixed soundtrack.

This was one of my favourite childhood games on the Sega Master System. Discovering the remake was a total surprise, and I remembered there was a guy I used to chat to long ago during the golden age of emulation about Sega, Wonder Boy and so on. I knew that guy loved WB3, and wondered if he knew about the project. Imagine my surprise seeing that he was in fact the guy behind the remake.

I've bought a lot of retro remakes (not to be confused with emulated ports) and they're varying degrees faithful to the originals, I don't always like the art style and so on. But this plays true (I believe the original game code is executing in the background, although at 60 FPS rather than 30) and the art is absolutely charming and perfectly fitting. A real labor of love. The ability to switch seamlessly between remake and original graphics and audio is a really nice touch.

Should you buy the game if you have never played the original? Yes - it's a timeless classic. Think of it more as a leisurely platformer than a true RPG though. It's more or less linear, but with a bunch of secrets (including a few new ones) to find. The Hard mode should keep people looking for more of a challenge entertained as the primary game is not that difficult, especially once you gear up.

Just so delighted this game exists. Thanks to Zoop and the rest of the development team.

NewGen trifft übergangslos auf OldSchool!

OMG wie ich es liebe! <3
Als Kind hab ich es auf dem Sega GameGear gezockt und kam aufgrund meines Alters an manchen Stellen nicht weiter weshalb ich dann immer nur so den Charakter wie im Rollenspiel durch die Welt geführt hab und mir "Quests" ausgedacht habe in den Levels welche mir offen Standen.
Irgendwann hab ich dann Random irgendwelche Passwörter eingegeben bis ich durch Zufall eines gefunden hatte was mich quasi ins Endgame versetzt hat mit allen Freischaltungen oder zumindest fast allen! :D

Nun hier hab ich mich nach Jahrzehnen direkt wieder zu Hause gefühlt.
So ein liebevoll gestaltetes Game hab ich schon ewig nicht gesehen.
Diese tolle, handgemalte Grafik ist unfassbar schön und die Neuvertonung ist sehr professionell gemacht worden.
Alles natürlich immer an das Orginalspiel angelehnt!
Man hat sogar die Möglichkeit während dem Spiel mit einem Tastendruck die Grafik zurück zur alten 8-bit-Grafik umzustellen genau wie der Sound. Dadurch sieht man erst, wie detailgetreu alles gestaltet ist bis hin zur Musik die natürlich nun im Orchestastyle gemacht wurde aber auch zurück auf die 8-bit-Musik gestellt werden kann und sich so super gleich anhören vom Beat. Das ist einfach toll! :)

Mich hat sofort die Nostalgie gepackt und erinnerte mich an die Welt und teile der Geheimnisse darin.
Hab es leider nie zuende gespielt als Kind und werde nun endlich die Gelegenheit haben es zu vollenden! :)

Die Steuerung fühlt sich super an und man fühlt sich nie so, als hätte man etwas nicht geschafft weil die Steuerung zu schwammig wäre. Im Gegenteil...man hat schnell raus wie alles funktioniert und kann unter umständen richtige Tricks machen um seine Gegner schneller zu beseitigen. :)
An kniffligen Stellen kann man mit Hilfe der 8-bit-Grafik schnell umschalten um genauer zu sehen wo welcher Pixel endet für einen gezielten Sprung. KLASSE! :)

Die Vielfalt dank der einzelnen Verwandlungen und der Rüstungen, Schwerter und Items macht das Jump'n'Run-Erlebnis gleichzeitig zu einem RolePlayGame in dem man nicht nur geschickt laufen und springen muss sondern auch kleine Rätsel löst und die Welt erkunden muss um weiter vorran zu schreiten.

Der Preis von knapp 20€ scheint im ersten Moment tatsächlich etwas happig zu sein doch dann als ich das Ergebnis gesehen habe und mich erkundigt hab was alles für Arbeit dahinter steckt, empfinde ich 20€ als genau den richtigen Preis für das was man hier geleistet hat.
Man hat nicht "nur" das Spiel portiert man hat es grafisch und soundtechnisch verbessert aber trotzdem die Möglichkeit gelassen den alten Look zu behalten...man hat also quasi 2 Spiele in einem. Einmal den "Port" bzw. "Das Orginal" und einmal "die schöne Version" bzw. "Das Remake". :)

In der Gallerie im Hauptmenu schaltet ihr beim Spiel div. Bilder, Zeichnungen, Gifs und Filmchen frei welche unteranderem den Prozess, also das Making-Of, näher bringen.
Grade das hat mir die Augen geöffnet wie viel Arbeit und Liebe darin steckt! 

Kann es jedem Jump'n'Run-Fan wärmstens empfehlen und auch jedem Nostalgie-Fan!
Neue Gamer wie auch alte Hasen werden hier gleichermaßen bedient und haben die Möglichkeit Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap so zu spielen UND zu hören wie sie es möchten! :) 

Wem 20€ doch zu teuer sind sollte spätestens im Sale nicht lange fackeln! Doch 20€ für das was die Devs hier fabriziert haben ist nicht nur der Preis für das Spiel sondern auch die Verbeugung vor einem tollen Spielehersteller der mehr hält als er verspricht...sowas muss unterstützt werden für weiterhin tolle Games! :)

32293279.review:
"WonderBoy - The Dragon's Trap" est un portage (français !!) du jeu vidéo éponyme, paru sur la SEGA Master System en 1989.
Il s'agit là du troisième opus de la série "WonderBoy".

(Attention, par portage j'entend que l'on a transposé tel quel le code d'un média sur un autre support que celui d'origine, ce qui à la base est bien le cas ici... MAIS cette rédition de 2017 propose également un rhabillage complet de l'oeuvre, autant graphiquement que musicalement.
Comprenez donc que le squelette du jeu est exactement le même que celui de l'époque, mais son apparence visuelle a quant à elle été complètement refondue avec un rendu "fait main" du plus bel effet).

Scénaristiquement, vous êtes victime d'une malédiction vous ayant fait perdre votre forme humaine au profit de celle d'un dragon(net).
Votre périple vous amènera à revêtir ainsi jusqu'à 5 formes animales diverses et à user de leurs spécificités pour enfin retrouver votre corps... ou pas.

Techniquement, c'est un jeu de plates-formes mâtiné d'éléments RPG (équipement, statistiques, inventaire, etc...) assez linéaire - les différentes régions deviennent accessibles au fur et à mesure des vos progrès, c'est-à-dire en explorant et triomphant des donjons de chacune d'elles.
Pas de système d'expérience ici, vos stats sont directement calculées en fonction des armes et armures équipées.
La courbe de difficulté est savamment dosée, et la monotonie latente du fameux triangle "HUB/donjon/boss" est régulièrement cassée par moult passages secrets, portes dérobées et pièces d'équipement rares qui rendent le tout finalement assez vite addictif, tant le rythme du jeu prête peu à s'arrêter.

Une mention spéciale pour la possibilité de switcher entre les graphismes HD ou d'époque à l'aide d'une simple pression sur la gâchette droite - idem pour les ziks réorchestrées ou en MIDI avec  une pression sur le stick analogique droit : on sent le travail de passionnés qui ont donné le meilleur d'eux-même pour restituer aux anciens gamers les sensations que procuraient ce soft autrefois !

EDIT : J'avais autrefois dénoncé l'absence incompréhensible de DLC comprenant l'excellente OST réorchestrée pour l'occasion de ce portage/remake mais le studio se veut à l'écoute de acomunauté de fans et n'as donc pas hésité par la suite à nous proposer un DLC très généreux en termes de contenus !

Je bouclerais cette évaluation en vous conseillant de regarder avec attention le générique de fin, ils ont eu une idée vraiment très sympa pour illustrer les noms du staff xD

Nell'epoca in cui i videogiochi erano fatti con passione incontaminata, quando ancora non erano un'industria milionaria, quando ancora non erano produzioni holliwoodiane piene di effetti speciali, nascevano piccoli capolavori come questo.

Il prodotto finale, il videogioco, non era progettato e studiato per soddisfare delle fredde leggi di mercato, soprattutto perché il "mercato" non esisteva; per questo i videogiochi somigliavano più a piccoli giocattoli realizzati artigianalmente piuttosto che a sofisticati e complessi film interattivi.

Giocare a Wonder Boy oggi è divertente come lo era negli anni '90. Nonostante sia un semplice e classico platform primordiale, si sente il "tocco umano" incondizionato.

I Lizardcube sono stati molto bravi a loro volta, perché con molta attenzione non hanno cambiato niente che potesse rimuovere queste sensazioni, dal canto loro hanno solo aggiunto rinnovato amore, ed il risultato è strepitoso.

32283169.review:
If you're over 30 years old, this will immediately bring you memories of your childhood. I didn't own a Master System myself back then, but seeing this immediately brought back to my mind the evenings of 1989 I spent with my friends playing this game.

This version is incredibly faithful to the original game, and the new animations do the game real justice, giving it the touch that technology in the late '80s would leave to our imagination. Everything that made this game so memorable is there - and by that I really mean it: the original Master System graphics and audio are there as well, and not just that, you can switch between original and remastered audio and graphics separately and on-the-fly!

tl;dr: Highly recommended!

32280160.review:
[h1]Five Stars: Masterpiece [/h1]

[b][u]Pros[/u][/b][list]
[*]The finest Mastersystem game, presented with fluid, beautiful animation and art quality.
[*]Outstanding soundtrack bears the leitmotifs of the original music, arranged uniquely per each level!
[*]You can actively switch between classic and revamped art/music as you play. 
[*]Modified to make the game more user-friendly (while still retaining all the challenge).
[/list]
[b][u]Cons[/u][/b][list]
[*]Kept me waiting almost THREE decades
[*]Certain secrets may stump (new) players
[*]Can't play with all these tears in my eyes
[*]This game used to take me days as a kid. How did I beat it in 5 hours? 
[/list]

If you've never played this champion of classic games, then this is absolutely the time to pick it up. It's one of the earliest metroidvanias but manages to bear very little backtracking. Though a little on the short side, it's concise and has no filler. The difficluty is no joke (hard will crush you). There's even plenty of little added secrets unique to this game. What you have here is a work of art and a real labor of love. The year is only half over but I'm confident this is the best indie title 2017 has for us.

32280021.review:
This is one of the best remastered games I've played.  The graphics, soundtrack, sound effects have all been drastically improved without changing any of the properties of the game. I was amazed at how the hit boxes and platforms feel the same as the original as I never thought I had to adjust my playstyle to accommodate the updated graphics.
 
This isn’t a 1:1 recreation but I felt the very few changes are for the better.  I doubt anyone will ever say they enjoyed grinding for charm stones just to buy new equipment or equip a certain sword to break stones. The added “Unknown Location” levels adds a new challenge for those who’ve already played every nook and cranny of this game whether 20+ years or just a few months ago.
 
Not only is this an awesome game to remaster(and very well done), it’s also a retro game that can be enjoyed by anyone and I believe the gameplay aged pretty well with its tight controls and simple pacing.

32279237.review:
This is an amazing piece of work. 

The love and craft that can be felt through this game is incredible. I played this growing up, writing all of the save codes across the manual that it came with. I remember the story, the characters. When I heard them say "Mouse Man" it wasn't until I saw who they were refering to until I said "Ah, they mean Mr Potato Head!" (that's how I saw him anywho)

They've lovingly remastered all of the original music, still keeping it's invigorating beats, and that artwork and animation is something to die for. 

Hot swapping between old and new? To be able to compare how each scene of the game has been adapted and changed, but is very much the same? That blew my mind.

I can't recomend this revamped version of a classic childhood game enough. For new players coming to the game, you'll struggle, you'll get lost. But that's part of the beauty of it, they've left it just as confusing as it was all those years ago.

Thanks to the wonderful team that's brought something that I used to have to dig out of my loft and blow the cartridge (and pray that it worked) to a platform that I can be close to each day. 

Well done guys,
You smashed it out of the park.

Brilliant example of how games should be remade.  If you were a fan of the original game and want to play through it again.  This is a must own title.  Not only did they stay true to the original... it is a "seemless" remake.  You can change it back and forth during game play and it even modulates the original chip tunes from the master system... even the FM chip.

So if you are not a fan of this game already let me explain a bit.  This is a classic action adventure game.  Wonder Boy back in the 80s/90s was a very popular series spawning several games.  Each one having a different but similar feel to them.  This one has charm by being able to be picked up and played and still having great depth to it kind of like a Zelda 2.  You explore around Monster Land and discover treasures like any other game.  However the charm of this game is brought out by the breathtaking artwork.  The original left much to be desired in the graphics department... this version has that and a more.

Seriously, if you want a fun game to just pick up and play this is a great title.  Especially if you are one of those retro game fans.  No it is not from the Nintendo it is from the superior Master System... bwahahaha jk jk.  This is a great game and it won't disappoint.

Une madeleine de Proust, voilà ce qu'est ce jeu. 

J'ai grandi  avec les CPC puis la SMS, j'ai passé du temps sur les Wonder Boy et c'est un plaisir de retrouver certains souvenirs qui remontent avec ce jeu.

La refonte graphique a un charme indéniable et la réinterprétation des thèmes originaux est très agréable, si vous avez moins de 20 ans, vous pouvez vous lancez dans l'aventure avec plaisir.

Pour les plus vieux, il est possible de retrouver les graphismes de la Master System à la pression d'un simple bouton (RT) et les sons/musiques (mais il faut passer par le menu des options).

La maniabilité n'a pas changé, vous allez parfois rager contre les masques de collision, mais la prise en main est simple et immédiate.

Je vous le conseille sans hésiter mais c'est peut être la fibre nostalgique qui me fait parler.

32270128.review:
Não sei nem por onde começar, primeira maior surpresa que tive, foi com o anúncio desse game maravilhoso, talvez não para muitos, mas acredito que várias pessoas tiveram sua infância marcada por esse jogo, talvez não como WonderBoy, mas como Turma da Mônica em: O Resgate. Tenho a fita guardada com muito carinho até hoje!

Esse Remaster (sim, considero um remaster por ser idêntico ao jogo original, mas com todas e excelentes melhorias), manteve toda a essência do game, ainda contando com a opção de poder trocar as músicas e os grafícos para o 8-bits a qualquer momento, nessa hora fica quão nítido foi esse salto de melhorias ao longo de todos esses anos.

32269028.review:
Saugeiles Spiel mit Einschränkung.
 
Ich kannte nur den ersten Teil damals vom Amiga her. 
War zu dem Zeitpunkt wohl ein Port von Sega. 
Dieses Spiel ist genauso genial wie Teil eins von damals. 
Die Retrografik ist eigentlich egal da die HD Grafik einfach zu knuddelig ist als das man umschaltet.
Die Steuerung geht super mit Controller. 

Ein rundum geniales Game.
Wären da nicht folgende zwei Negativ-Punkte im Spiel.

Ein entscheidender Negativ-Punkt ist die Schwierigkeit der Endgegner.
Der Zweite das fehlende Speichern an individuellen Punkten. 

Hänge als Beispiel derzeit mit Mouseman am Drachen fest. 
Gehe ewig tot beim Versuch den zu besiegen und muss dann immer wieder den Weg zum Drachen laufen. 
Noch macht es Laune weil das Game neu ist in meiner Bibliothek.
Wird aber ... wie ich vermute ... irgendwann nervig werden. 
Ich bin der Typ Spieler der beim zigsten Versuch des Scheiterns hinwirft und deinstalliert. 
Verständlich ... wenn man bedenkt das ich kein Jump n Run Profi bin.
Hätte mir gewünscht dass ein Speicherpunkt jeweils am Endgegner erstellt wird. 
Oder eine Möglichkeit dorthin zu porten wenn man diesen einmal erreicht hat. 
Zumindest in der Schwierigkeit Leicht hätte ich mir das gewünscht. 
Wenn man aber immer und immer wieder drauf geht und einen elendigen langen Weg laufen muss um abermals zu verlieren ist das mehr als nur Strafe ... es wird zur Tortur. 

Grundsätzlich gibt es einen Daumen hoch ... alles Andere wäre unfair. 
Aber durch dieses fehlende individuelle Speichern bzw. den fehlenden Engegner-Direkt-Ports  gebe ich dem Spiel nur 6 von 10 möglichen Punkten. 
Es ist einfach für mich ein zu hoher Frußt-Faktor ... daher der enorme Abstrich an Punkten. 
Wer allerdings auf sowas kann hat mit Wonderboy - The Dragons Trap sicher mehr als Fun.

Wie auch immer!?

Für 19,99 Euro macht man grundsätzlich nichts falsch und kann getrost als Jump n Run Fan zugreifen. 
Zu teuer ist es jedenfalls nicht.

32266822.review:
This game simply sets the new standards for what a remake should be. Somptuous graphics, amazing soundtrack, keeping the simple but powerful gameplay of the original game. Extremely faithful to the original game.

For those who don't know the original, this mostly a platformer, with some rpg elements (gold/equipment), and an unusual character progression, where each boss fight will transform you in a different character, with totally different skills and characteristics (one is smaller, one can fly, one can break some blocks, etc). Those skills almost always allow you to access new zones in places you already visited, making the world feel really big. It's also full of hidden secrets with really clever level design.

Only disappointment might be the new hard difficulty, that doesn't really add much to the game. All it does is make you lose a bit of health regularly, which doesn't impact much the game as much as it sounds (as long as you max potions before leaving for a long trip, or know where to farm them on the way).

Game is also very accessible, I'd recommend it at any age. Do not expect a lot of guidance though, even if there's a bit more information than on the original game, you still have to pretty much figure out everything by yourself.

Edit after a bit longer in game: some new zones have been added, and modify one mechanic of the original game (the charm stone one, that was quite obscure originally). While the idea is interesting, the design of those new zones feels one big step below the original ones.

A fantastic remake of one of my all time favourite games. 

WonderBoy/WonderGirl/WonderBoy 3 (whatever you want to call it) is one of those games where you just keep coming back for more because while it initially appears to be a standard platformer, as time goes you appreciate the amount of depth it really contains. 

I guess it could be called a metroidvania game but with a twist; the twist being that instead of specific items being used to unlock abilities and therefore granting access to previously inaccessible areas, you change forms - and there are quite a few on offer here.

The music is SUPERB!! I'll tell you that I was whistling the tune to this after god knows how long since I last played it, which is testament to how great the music really is. It would be great if DotEmu offered an OST as part of a deluxe version here which I feel is a missed opportunity.

All in all a fantastic remake of a fantastic game. Just get it!

32266439.review:
It's Wonderful!  That's why he's called WONDER Boy (or Girl.)

Unlike a number of people reviewing this game, this is my first sojourn into the Dragon's Trap.  I never had a Sega Master System so this review will be done with the viewpoint of someone coming into the game for the first time.

Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap is one the of first Metroidvanias, even preceding that of the famous Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.  It is the second of the Monster World series (and the third Wonder Boy game) and a direct sequel of the first game, Wonder Boy in Monster Land.  It shares a lot of elements with Symphony and like it, begins right off at the end of another game, in this case: Wonder Boy in Monster Land.  You will also be locked out of certain areas until you cleared a previous one first and gaining an item or ability that enable access.  

While Monster Boy in Monster Land was originally an arcade game (and ported to various systems), The Dragon's Trap was a console-only exclusive of the Sega Master System, the Nintendo Entertainment System's direct rival.

Fast forward, decades later.  Now we have this, Wonderboy: the Dragon's Trap developed and remade by Lizardcube.  

The first thing to remember is at it's essence, it still is the same game as the original, meaning it has the typical length of a title of this kind for an 8-bit system.  Thus for anyone unfettered by nostalgic memories of playing the original, even with all its bells and whistles, any expectations of enjoying the length of a typical Metroidvania made in 1997 and beyond will be sorely disappointed.  It took me a few hours to win and only because of the few instances of getting stuck and wandering around before I could figure out what to do next.

I knew all this beforehand, that I was buying an 8-bit SMS title essentially and it was going to be pretty short.  So why did I buy this in the first place?  The wonderful art and the music, that's why!  The aestethics was just that good.  From the minute I saw the trailer, I knew I had to get it.

If you've been weaned on French style comic books like Asterix, Iznogoud and Ompa-Pa, you'll notice a resemblance in it's rugged detailed style.  The art is wonderful and the game animates like a dream (even on my old outdated laptop), like one of those aformentioned comics coming to life.

The music still uses the same score created by Shinichi Sakamoto in the SMS version but Lizardcube re-presents these same old tunes to be performed by professional musicians.  No midi tunes or techno, you will hear saxophones, pianos, flutes and more as you traipse all over Monster Land and it sounds glorious.  Like Akumajyou Densetsu (Castlevania 3 Japanese version) which I played for so many hours, it's a joy to re-play this game again and again just to listen to the wonderful music.

I played the first game, Wonder Boy in Monster Land in an Amiga 500 and always wanted to play the sequel.  Now I do and I've never been happier that I waited for so long and end up playing this marvelous remake.

32265675.review:
This is probably my favorite game from when I was a child, I still have the Game Gear cart with my old-school console collection and it is one of the games, I've always strove to keep with me wherever I went, even though I only beat it at a teenager. For someone like me, this remake is like a dream come true, that one thing you never actually think was gonna happen but actually does.

Graphics:

If you've been following the trailers/hype up to release, you'll have noticed that the guys over at LizardCube tried to re-create the game to the best of their ability and I have to say that even though I have a soft-spot for the original graphics (which don't look as bad as I expected at 1080p), the updated visuals look amazingly gorgeous and I find myself swapping between retro and updated on the go because I can't make up my mind about which to keep. The UI in retro mode also got a few tweaks and looks much cooler now.

Music: 

Starting with nostalgia again, they have kept everything from the original game, both sound effects and music and when I started playing, which I did with new GFX + retro sounds, it just felt like I was a kid again playing on my Game Gear. Then I went for old GFX +new sounds and music and was amazed at how well it fits. It's almost like playing an orchestral score of the original, considering all the variety of instruments used. I'd love to see an OST released for this, would buy it asap.

Gameplay:

Whether you play with the old or new GFX, the gameplay is identical as the original game you know and love (with the momentum slide when you stop moving too). If you're not acquainted with the gameplay of the original, think NES Zelda 2, but with good control and better graphics. It's a 2D platformer with light RPG mechanics (equipment, spellcasting - that you gather as drops as you explore the world and kill monsters), but the true meat of the game is its overworld. It's almost like a Metroidvania but not quite. There is a central hub-town you start at that you can explore more and more depending on which monster form you happen to be at the moment. The new parts you get access to will lead you to new areas where you will eventually enter a dungeon and face a new dragon. The controls are responsive and the character does what you ask it to when you ask it to. Just like in the original :P

Plot:

A dragon screwed and cursed you. Now you will get your revenge... and murder his entire family in the process. Ok, maybe it's not quite like that but close enough!

Other notes:

I love the added humor in new GFX mode. Fits the light tone of the game like a glove. I also love that touch of being able to change the title screen from Wonder Boy to Wonder Girl by pressing A on it.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'll give this game a very strong thumbs up. It's true to the original in every way and the new art and music make it an absolute joy to both ears and eyes.

Thank you LizardCube for this game, and thank you DotEmu for giving these guys a way to distribute their game.

38956206.review:
Though the looks may have updated, it still retains the classic feel of the game its based off of.  Which is great, because you can jump straight back to retro style immediately, and reuse your old save codes.  It also has secrets. Actual secrets. The kind you wouldn't be able to find without a walkthrough, trying everything, or by complete accident.  It can be slightly infuriating at times with the same stupid enemy knocking you off that one platform, but that's just the old-school charm.

My only real complaint is because its an old game, some sections and powers feel like you hardly get to use them at all before they are never needed again.  This is more a criticism of the base material, but it feels like powers were mostly about letting you access certain zones, and their individual special mechanics weren't needed much beyond that.  I don't see how the sunken ship is enhanced by being a piranha-man other than needing it to board.

But again, those complaints are mostly to do with the base game, and not with the remake.  Its a rather excellent remake, keeping the visuals and music close to their source material while still rendering them in HD if you want them, and even makes a point of deliberately leaving in typographical errors.  Its hard to get closer to the source than that.

40751077.review: I never heard of this game until the remaster here on Steam even though I was around when the original came out.  Honestly, this game only popped up on my radar because of the "Nostalgia" trailer for it where it showed it switching back and forth between HD remake and classic look...SOLD! I mean instantly.  I waited for it to go on sale as I do with every game I want for Steam, and man it was worth the wait.  The visuals alone are 5 stars.  Then you add in the ability to switch video AND audio between present and retro, just adds to the pot.  If you're a fan of old school games that just drop you in and let you figure it out, this is the game for you.  There's no hand holding like modern games, which I love too, but sometimes I wish they didn't "tell" you to push a certain button when you're next to something interactive, I wish they just left it up to your imagination to wonder IF something can be interacted with, and the excitement in finding out you were right.  This is a classic platforming adventure game, ala the days of Super Mario Bros, except you can go back to places you've visited any time you like.  The different characters to play with have their pros and cons, switching up the gameplay all throughout play.  My only 2 cons to this game is...1, Lion Man, he's not really in the game that much I feel, as a useful character, which is slightly good since he's ridiculously strong compared to the others.  2, the final boss is literally the easiest boss of all.  In fact, I felt the bosses got easier as the game went on.  However, those 2 things didn't stop me from being amazed at what a good job the old and new developers did with the game, and it was definitely worth  the price.  I don't want it to become a gimmick to be greedy, but more "remakes" should be like this.  A splash of new for the younger generation, but the same of what made the game great in the first place.

40745832.review:
It's a cute as heck, competent platformer that is, somewhat unfortunately, a 1:1 remake of a Sega Master System title. Aside from streamlining the password system into autosaves, nothing about the gameplay has been changed, and the game carries all the flaws of the original - lacking bossfights, short length and poorly explained mechanics to name a few.

It's still a lot of fun, but it's only a lot of fun for around 4 hours. Up to you whether that sounds worth $20 or not.
I hope Lizardcube gets an opportunity to build something more extensive off the franchise, or make their own game in the future, because the art, audio and overall style of the game is A++ and it wouldn't take much to turn Wonderboy into something truly outstanding of they were to break away a little bit from the 1989 design of the original.

40484203.review:
[h1]前言：[/h1]
首先说一下因为我并没有接触过小霸王学习机上的《神奇小子》或者类似的红白机游戏[spoiler] （西游记？)[/spoiler]所以如果有误解的地方请原谅。我个人认为这是一款更适合作为游戏史上进化史般的教科书式游戏，也就是说更适合用来作为对下一代玩家或者是大学游戏专业讲课的教材。

[h1]游戏画面：[/h1]
《神奇小子：龙之陷阱》的画风非常有特色：精致的图案设计，色调暖而明亮，配合上令人惊艳的手绘风格，不由让玩家眼前一亮。无论是人物还是怪物设计都是矮胖矮胖的，给人一种萌萌哒的感觉。玩家将随着进程体验到炽热的火山、危机四伏的森林、寒冷的深海、神秘的金字塔等有特色的地图。制作者还给以玩家更多的画面选择，你可以无缝的在上世代FC红白机画质和复刻版手绘画风中切换成你所想要的。

[h1]游戏音效：[/h1]
同样玩家在复刻画风和红白机画风下有着两种风格完全不同的背景音乐。游戏结尾配合上开发人员的老照片真是让人在感慨的同时给与这些游戏制作者无穷的敬意。

[h1]游戏系统：[/h1]
包含了血量系统、道具系统、装备系统、商店系统和变身系统。虽然说在现代游戏中都是玩家司空见惯的设计，但是放在上世代红白机中，这就是相当丰富且有创意的设计了，其理念可以说想当的超前。因为小时候家里管的严，只体验过比较常见的马里奥、魂斗罗、马戏团之流。所以我认为如果回到那个时代《神奇小子》绝对属于当时游戏素质最顶尖的一批。在游戏中你可以体验到五种不同的角色：皮皮龙、飞鹰、狮子、老鼠、鱼人。他们都有着各自的特殊能力，只要能灵活运用游戏难度会降低很多。

[h1]地图设计：[/h1]
收集资料的时候发现了药荚大佬的科普，才了解到原版本游戏也是属于关卡式，不过在复刻后改为了半开放式游戏，算是结合时代的转变吧，你可以反复去到以前的地图进行探索。

[h1]游戏手感：[/h1]
看到很多玩家说这款游戏动作设计很“滑”在我的印象中很多FC红白机游戏也是这个手感，稍微习惯一下操作还是没有问题的。不过令我比较反感的是人物碰撞后的硬直还有短时间内无免伤效果还是让人很绝望的。对我这个中度手残来说BOSS只能全靠拼血过。

[h1]总结：[/h1]
+令人惊艳的手绘画风
+上世代的情怀
+游戏厂商的坚持
+优秀的音乐
-过时的玩法
-令人懊恼的BUG和设定

[h1]后记：[/h1]
因为从现代流行的游戏设计（游戏模式）来说，这无疑是上个世代的游戏通病，也是横版闯关游戏逐渐成为小众游戏的原因。但是在如今让人眼花缭乱的游戏界，从文字小黄油《NEKOPARA》到3A开放世界巨作的《巫师：狂猎》[spoiler] 大。。。大黄油？[/spoiler]《神奇小子》的复刻不是没有意义的。他让玩家在缅怀过去的基础上不由自主的想要探寻未来游戏模式的发展方向，能够看清这一切的无疑将成为游戏界的新霸主。

感谢各位能一路看到这里。如果您觉得还可以请点一个赞哦。

40400736.review:
I'm a bit mixed on this game but I've had a fun time with it overall.

I think the first thing you need to be aware of is that this game is a [b]remake to the bone![/b] Besides the newly made, [u][i]gorgeous[/i][/u] visuals and music, this is essentially the same game as it was back on the Sega Master System. (The game even allows you to switch between both the new and the original graphics and music.) That means that the level designs and all of the mechanics have been remade to feel exactly like they did back then.

This is fine if you have played the original game before, however anyone else will have to get accustomed to the rather awkward controls of this game. Jumping and attacking feels quite stiff compared to newer games, getting hit knocks you back etc. These are not necessarily bad things, but you need to be aware that this is what you're getting into. Some enemies can be quite annoying to deal with at first because of these rather old school controls.

Unfortunatly, they also had to stay faithful to some flaws of the original as well. I'd say the worst part about this game are probably the bosses. They aren't necessarily hard, but when you encounter them for the first time, they're simply annoying to fight against, simply because they can just stunlock you for multiple seconds until you figure out their pattern and how to best attack them with the before mentioned awkward controls.
Some levels can feel a bit uninspired at certain points, either by recycling rooms or having a level just be a boring hallway with enemies.

Then there's minor but still annoying quirks, like having to go through all of your animal forms until you transform into the one that you want or having to wait for your enemies to disappear and droping their items before you can pick them up, hampering the flow of the game.
I can't really fault the developers for this too much, since they tried to create a faithful remake, but to me, they're issues nonetheless.

As I mentioned before though, I did enjoy the game. It is challenging, mostly due to the before mentioned issues, but not at all impossible to beat. I also really have to give credit to the art and music department of this game.

Overall, if you're willing to put up with the rather old school mechanics and quirks of this game, or you've already played the original and are already used to them, I think this game is well worth it.

Note: A regular playthrough will last ~4-5 hours. After that, there's some secret levels and collectibles, as well as a hard mode. If you're not a completionist, I'd wait for a sale.

40366658.review:
[h1] Um remaster muito bom, mas como jogo, não tanto	[/h1]
Bem, sempre é muito bonito rever um clássico numa versão remasterizada, e falando nisso, essa é uma das melhores remasterizações que já joguei, pelo menos na parte artística. O jogo revive muito a sensação de nostalgia, enredo simples, o mundo foi tomado por monstros, você tem uma missão, e você realiza ela, sem mais dramas. Você pode alternar entre a música e a arte retrô a QUALQUER MOMENTO, o que eu achei FANTASTICO, se quiser jogar com gráficos atuais e musica retrô você pode, e vice e versa. 

O jogo artisticamete ficou muito lindo, mostra o empenho que foi usado. Porém, o jogo não ficou mil maravilhas não, infelizmente. Utilizaram as mesmas mecânicas que o jogo antigo, deixaram exatametne igual, ou seja, controles imprecisos, aquela sensação horrível de tomar dano e sair quicando pelo cenário sem poder fazer NADA e ficar trancado as vezes por uns 30 segundos pq fica tomando dano. Se as mecânicas tivessem sido implementadas, o jogo teria sido MUITO melhor, e sem dúvidas teria sido muito mais conhecido. Quando comecei a jogar, eu estava babando pelo jogo, infelizmente ele foi decepcionando um pouco.
GRÁFICOS/APARÊNCIA: 10/10 (remaster gráfico perfeito, 2D muito bem feito)
TRILHA SONORA: 7.5/10 (muito boa, mas muito "repetitiva")
DIFICULDADE: 5/10 (quase nula, se equipar os equipamentos corretos. Só tive dificuldade no Boss final, pois estava sem o escudo correto)
JOGABILIDADE: 4/10 (não é uma jogabilidade péssima, mas também não é uma jogabilidade boa, manteram a mesma de 30 anos atrás)

TOTAL: 7.5/10 
O jogo é muito bonito, encanta muito, e me fez babar, artisticamente é ótimo. Infelizmente um jogo não é apenas arte, mas um conjunto de vários elementos, entre eles a jogabilidade, o que ele pecou bastante. Para um Remaster ficou MUITO BOM, mas se tivessem incrementado as mecânicas, e colocado um pouco mais de cenários (zerei o jogo em 5 horas, o que é um tempo muito curto) com certeza o jogo teria ficado absurdo.

40297485.review:
声明

游戏来源于STCN：https://steamcn.com/
STCN鉴赏家：http://store.steampowered.com/curator/255962/
完整图文评测：https://steamcn.com/t356284-1-1
感谢STCN鉴赏家给与我此次评测的机会！





優缺點彙總

加分項

+ 良心的手绘风画面
+ 大手笔的音乐编曲
+ 极具创意的切换效果
+ 有趣的道具收集系统
+ 特色的附身系统
+ 二次创作生动有趣



扣分項

- 令人不适的操作手感
- 剧情仍未充分补完





        《Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap》几乎做到了重置游戏的极致：保持高还原度的同时，极大地加强了声色体验。其手绘画面风格和大手笔的音乐改编也是近年来重置游戏中少有的大投入。假如你是个怀旧向玩家，更能随时在游戏中切换回8-bit模式，回忆童年的欢乐时光。而且这款游戏也加入了非常有意思的二次设定和人物对白，更是平添了一些诙谐风趣。

        而说回游戏本身，主角有着六种形态的变化，每种形态所能越过的障碍都不同，攻击模式也不相同。而这就和《洛克人》系列有着异曲同工之妙了。作为30年前的游戏，能想到做装备与道具系统可以是是非常有前瞻性的。玩家在游戏过程中打败敌人，获取战利品金币，然后再购置装备，增加自己的攻击力与防御力，这让这款作品再现在看来有着ARPG的雏形。

        然而由于年代的久远，保持着30年前作品操作手感的《Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap》放到今天，则令人非常不适应。在操作角色时，玩家感受到的横板动作类游戏中常见的冰上行走。短时间特定场景以此增加难度还算是有趣味，然而整作都是这样的操作手感的话，就使得该作有着一定的劝退属性。

        另外，个人还希望《Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap》将剧情补完的更全面，这样能使玩家有着更强的代入感。




遊戲短評

        说起《神奇小子》，可能很多人并不熟悉，然而说到高桥名人《冒险岛》系列，还有《西游记》，必然会勾起很多玩家的同年回忆。经查阅后发现，这款30年前的经典作品，竟和以上两个著名游戏是一个妈生的。而更有一种说法，《冒险岛）、《西游记》是《神奇小子》的换皮作品。那这样一款始祖级的游戏到底表现如何呢？

        这款游戏玩起来和当年的《西游记》一样有趣，通过商店购买装备提升战斗力，在宝箱中找到道具，如恶魔城那样的场景型地图，这些要素放到今天竟仍然不过时。更良心的是，这款游戏原汁原味的还原了当年的8-bit画面和音乐，并且基于这样的画面和音乐作了很多手绘绘图，以及重新编曲，在游戏中玩家可以自由的切换手绘风格现代画面和8-bit画面，也可以自由切换重新编曲的现代化音乐和8-bit音乐。

        在游戏性上，这款游戏基本是将原来游戏模式照搬到了电脑屏幕前，并没有作什么改动。这也就意味着，玩家感受到30年前的动作游戏玩法势必会感受到一些不适应。想一想那时候的经典游戏：《恶魔城》、《洛克人》、《魔界村》甚至《冒险岛》，哪个游戏放到今天操作起来，能入得了平台动作游戏玩家的法眼？因此，面对这样的操作手感，我们也可以回顾一下当年那些动作游戏的风格，其实也是挺好。

        对于这种重置类作品，定位是非常明确的，怀旧向玩家可以考虑入手。

40285208.review:
"Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap" es el inesperado remake de la tercera entrega de la saga Wonder Boy, publicada para Sega Master System en 1989. Y se trata de un remake en el más estricto sentido de la palabra, ya que estamos ante exactamente el mismo juego con un lavado de cara (y qué lavado). ¿Y eso es bueno o malo? Pues... Un poco de cada.

Es muy bueno por un motivo, y solo uno: El apartado artístico. Tanto en lo visual como en lo sonoro estamos ante un trabajo sublime por parte de los artistas que se han encargado de adaptar el aspecto gráfico y la música. Concretamente, una persona para cada uno.
El resultado es impecable. Cuesta creer que una sola persona haya realizado todas las ilustraciones y animaciones que conforman el juego, desde los personajes principales hasta el último detalle que puebla cada escenario. La estética cartoon está logradísima, mimada al máximo, y hablo en serio cuando digo que merece la pena jugar el juego solo por su estética. Una delicia para la vista, y un acto de amor a la obra original.
En cuanto al apartado musical, también destaca, con unas versiones muy buenas de los temas originales. Pero es que, a pesar de su calidad, se ve eclipsado por todo lo visual que tendremos en pantalla a cada momento.

Cuando hablo de que es un remake exacto del juego original me refiero a que se han imitado con total exactitud todos sus escenarios y mecánicas de juego, respetando la posición, físicas y funcionamiento de todo. Esto es así hasta tal punto que con un solo botón podremos alternar entre el aspecto del juego original y el remake, en cualquier momento. Un gran trabajo de fidelidad llevado al extremo.

Y sin embargo es aquí donde encontramos a la vez el que en mi opinión es el único punto débil del juego. "Wonder Boy III", a pesar de ser un gran juego en su momento, no ha envejecido demasiado bien para las mecánicas de juego actuales, y determinados aspectos de la jugabilidad pueden echar para atrás a más de uno. Es un juego que, a pesar de su aspecto, se ajusta a la vieja escuela al máximo, lleno de secretos que nadie te va a indicar, de repetición de niveles enteros por morir al final de los mismos, y de decisiones que a día de hoy se considerarían cuestionables, así como una dificultad un tanto ajustada en algunos puntos (sin llegar a desesperar, eso sí, salvo algún reto opcional).
No me malinterpretéis, el juego es totalmente disfrutable, a mí me ha gustado mucho, pero creo que hay que afrontarlo teniendo muy en cuenta lo que es: Un juego de 1989, y no un juego actual.

Es a esto a lo que me refiero con que la decisión de hacer este remake totalmente fiel al juego original tiene su lado bueno y su lado malo. Pero lo que sí puedo decir es que, mirando las animaciones de nuestro personaje y los escenarios por los que se mueve, se nos olvidará lo malo muy pronto.

40264182.review:
Like a lot of American gamers, I have limited experience with games originating on the SMS platform.  I was drawn to the art style and the idea of old school platforming, and to the game's credit, it seems to have replicated that not only faithfully but with the ability to flip back and forth between modern and rerto.  Moreover, the re-made soundtrack builds upon the core tracks with variations on a theme, presenting new instrumentals in settings that would have otherwise replayed the same track from other areas.

At the same time, while it's interesting from a gaming history standpoint as a proto-Metroid built out from a single hub, I finished the normal game in about four and a half hours after bumping around a bit and some initial struggles with the difficulty spikes.  Armed with this sense of the game and how it operated, I stopped and thought to myself after finishing dinner one evening, "can I just beat hard mode now, before going to bed?"  Two hours later, it turned out I could and did.

It's not a bad game and was obviously a labor of love on the part of the creators, but it is a limited game for its price tag at $20 and I've spent far more time on releases that I've paid less for.  If you're a historian of gaming and want the experience of what was really good platforming in the late 80s, go for it.  Even with the technical limitations, it's still engaging.  But it's also a game that you can hit 100% on in under ten hours, and I feel like after two playthroughs, I "get it," but don't have much incentive to ever go back.

40245663.review: Una joya, así es como deberían ser todas las remasterizaciones, además con el extra de jugar con la ost de 8bits  y los gráficos del original.

40241514.review:
I love the Sega Master System, and it disappoints me that it never got popular despite having some really awesome titles. This is easily one of the top five games for that system, right along the likes of Sonic the Hedgehog or Aleste. Needless to say, that means I'd have to hold this HD remake to a very high standard, since nothing is worse than a lazy remake of a great game (Super Street Fighter II Turbo HD comes to mind), and fortunately it exceeds those standards. The hand-drawn graphics definitely look nice, making a pixelated 8-bit game look like an actual cartoon, and give the game more depth than it previously had. The backgrounds are no longer just solid colors, they have pyramids, fields, and scrolling layers. The characters no longer stand completely still like a cardboard cutout, they actually breathe and have idle animations the original lacked. Same goes for the sound department, rather than hearing beeps and boops, the fire sounds like fire, footsteps sound like footsteps, and you can even hear birds chirping like when you walk outside in real life. The reorchestrated music is also done very well, though I prefer the original 8-bit soundtrack myself. Fortunately, lizardcube accounted for this, and made it possible to switch between retro and modern graphics and sound. I personally love the new graphics, but want the original sound, and I can do that. They even accounted for the fact that the original game's soundtrack could be rendered on both the Master System's PSG chip and the FM unit only released in Japan. You want modern graphics and sound effects, but the FM or PSG music? You can do that. Original graphics, but modern sound effects and music? You can do that. The best part is that you can switch between all of this in game, so you don't need to return to the title screen every time you want to change aesthetics. Not only that, but the game does this seamlessly, with no drop in framerate. I don't lock the framerate at all (though you can if you want to), and the game still runs at a consistent 75 fps, with no drops whatsoever. I imagine on a less powerful PC, this would probably run at 60 fps instead, but even then, you're getting a game that looks and plays buttery smooth. Speaking of gameplay, this game also has autosave, so you no longer have to write down passwords if you want to pick up where you left off. 
Overall, I just can't recommend this remake enough, even if you're like me and can play the original on a real Master System or Genesis via its backwards compatibility. Between the customizable aesthetics, superior framerate, and autosave, there's no reason to even need the original game anymore, as this was a meticulously crafted 21st Century upgrade that outshines it in every sense of the imagination. This is how games should be remade, as a project of love and compassion, and not just some quick cash grab. For $20, this is a must-have. Keep up the phenomenal work, Lizardcube, and I'll be looking forward to your next release.

40206334.review:
[code]*中国鉴赏家同好会[开发者要请]评测
*开发者要请评测由开发者邀请同好会成员免费测试游戏的方式，最终产生的玩家评测,故该评测仅作为参考，望读者理性阅读，谨慎购买。[/code]

当我知道这款游戏的时候还是通过女流的直播才发现的，在气人主播的游玩下，我发现还是自己买回来才能体会游戏的精髓。于是我有幸通过了牵线鉴赏家得到了这款游戏，以下是我的游戏心路历程。

在我玩之前翻阅浏览了游戏相关资料，得知这是SEGA《神奇小子3》的重置版，也就是很像我们小时候玩到的任天堂的《冒险岛》以及《西游记》，这让我的期待值一下上升了一个高度，在我童年时期，留下了很多深刻的印象，陪伴了数月时间。时隔数年，这款充满着8-bit时代欢乐与笑声的游戏披着全新的美术外衣再一次来到了我们的眼前。冲着那精致的手绘风格，我就有了上手一玩的兴致，作为《马里奥》同时代的游戏，不知是否有着相同的童趣。

说到重置版，大多数玩家都会想到“炒冷饭”“伊织（移植）”等词语，暂且不说是那些厂商过多的做出此类行为，最起码我认为单纯加个HD的后缀，不足以算是一个多棒的重置版。那怎样才算一个合格的重置版呢？这款《神奇小子：龙之陷阱》就是一个很好的例子。

从画面上来讲，他足以成功吸引到大批玩家，在看惯了那些画面炫酷的3A大作之后，《神奇小子》的手绘画风看起来真是清新脱俗。游戏还专门为玩家们准备了一键切换旧版像素风格与音乐的“复古键”，按下之后让人瞬间回想起当初那段废寝忘食拼命玩游戏的岁月，而正是因为可以这样随意切换进行对比，才能发现游戏真的在画面上花了不少功夫，对于这种手法对我而言十分符合我的胃口。

讲述了一个很简单的奇幻故事，你将扮演一位年轻的勇者，为了拯救世界于危难之中进军魔龙城堡之时中了魔龙的诅咒，能力尽失，变成了怪物，危机之中只能逃出生天，回望火光中的决战城堡，旧的故事结束，新的冒险旅途随之展开，接下来我们就需要不断的在这个世界中探索，取得各种各样的怪物能力，目的是寻回失去的力量，干掉魔龙，解除诅咒，恢复人型。

游戏采用半开放世界的设计，没有严格的关卡安排，随意进行各种探索，获得的能力不断增多变强，可探索的区域自然也就慢慢扩大，如果你在红白机上玩过《冒险岛》的话，想必会找回当年熟悉的味道。

本作作为一个标准的ARPG游戏，当然必不可少的打怪掉金币，收获了这些丰富的金币之后，我们可以拿这些金币通过商店购买自己想要的装备以及恢复生命值，而在四处探险的过程中，也能收获相当多的装备道具。游戏中的装备系统设计的相当完善，装备的种类分为消耗道具、武器、盾牌和盔甲，虽说种类数目上并不是很丰富，但是需要注意的地方是其中的特殊效果。在每种变身不同的形态下，武器装备所得到的加成属性都是不同的，可以这么理解有些装备适合鱼人，有些装备适合狮子、老鼠等等。除此之外，很多装备都有着独特的技能，例如哈迪斯盔甲可以让你额外多一条生命，龙之盔甲则是让你不受岩浆区域的伤害，当觉得游戏越来越困难的时候，不妨试着切换一下装备，也许会有意想不到的惊喜。

还有需要注意的是游戏在地图中安排了许多隐藏的暗门，甚至有些几乎没有任何的提示与标识，基本只能靠误打误撞或者一些多动症患者才能发现，一旦发现其中很有可能存放着相当不错的大宝贝，有些提示需要切换一下模式才能发现。这样一来虽然整体的地图不大，但是依旧值得来回反复探索几次。由于本作只是一个重置版，所以在流程长度方面上不算太丰富，通关耗时大约也就是4-5个小时左右，当然这并不意味着通关就等于完美，在游戏通关之后，你才会明白当主角变回人型，随之游戏难度也会增加，以及更多的隐藏关卡等着你去攻克。

虽然有这么多好处以及绝赞的画面，但是不可否认他有一坨屎一样的操作，旧时代僵硬的手感，以及脚底仿佛抹了油一样的角色移动，各种不人性化的设计，都以情怀之名一并继承了过来。在这种操作下游玩整个游戏的关卡体验中，给人带来了强烈的挫败感，让全程体验变得非常不愉快，让原本轻轻松松就能达成的目标，变得需要反反复复多次尝试，甚至各种阴沟里翻船。（深有体会在直播的游玩的时候，各种被弹幕嘲笑手残T_T）

这部没有足够的流程，也缺乏人性化的引导，继承情怀与趣味性的前提下，改善那些蹩脚的旧时代操作，想必会有更好的表现。可惜的是在缺点和优点一并继承下来之后，情怀果然可贵，但是又有多少人愿意无条件承受那份情怀中的反人类之重呢？更何况那些以前没有玩过同类早期作品的玩家，这么棒的美术，要是在游戏感受上更为玩家考虑我觉得它很有可能成为受欢迎的好作品。

40104481.review:
[b] My personal history of the original Wonder Boy III [/b]

I have very fond memories of the original Sega Master System version of this game. The whole presentation was so charming and the game was so much more intruiging than anything I had played up to that point (circa 1992-1993). The open world feel of the game, the sense of globetrotting between totally differently themed locations as well as the shape shifting really kept me on the edge of my seat, just waiting to see what would happen next. When I grew older I regretfully got rid of the Sega Master System, but every now and then in recent years I've been looking at Youtube videos of rankings of the best games for that console. Wonderboy III: The Dragon's Trap tends to sit at #1 or #2 in those rankings.   

[b] My review of this remake [/b]

I've been aware of the existence of this remake for quite some time, but it took until now for me to finally give it a try. I'm playing with  a controller, which  I think is mandatory for a game like this. The first thing that strikes me is of course the updated visuals. The hand drawn visual style is really reminiscent of Disney movies from the early to mid 90's. The music has been recorded with real-life instruments. One cool detail is how the dungeon theme is recorded with different instruments and in different arrangements depending on the setting in the game. The spooky version from the shipwreck level is my favorite, closely followed by the one from the ninja temple.

The whole presentation is very faithful to the original game. In fact, with the press of a button you can swap to the 8-bit version. This is done via a quick scrolling effect, so there is no perceived delay when switching between the old and the new. This is a neat feature that highlights how faithful this remake really  is. At times I even get a bit moved by how much love for the source material that shines through in this remake. It is really a labour of love from people who understand the appeal of the old game, as opposed to merely a fresh coat of paint.

Gameplay wise this is Wonder Boy III: The Dragon's Trap as it was back then. There is little to no handholding, so you need to explore the world, find secrets and buy the appropriate gear before you approach the next stage or dungeon. On one of my recent playthroughs I forgot to buy a particular sword and as a result I did almost zero damage to the boss in the ninja temple. Secrets play a big role and just knowing where there is a hidden door may net you an extra life and a full health refill before a boss fight.  All in all your first playthrough might take you around 4-5 hours, but it can be finished in less than two hours once you get the hang of it.
 
[b]My verdict:[/b] 
Two thumbs and one lizard's tail up for this one!

40041139.review:
[h1] Wonder boy is Wonderful! [/h1]

[h1] Story: [/h1] This delightful tale, takes you on an adventure. It's a side scrolling, entertaining experience.  The story gives you a choice of a male/female character and allows you to enter a castle.  Unfortunately you fall under a curse and each each boss you beat gives you a different kind of change. There's not so much dialogue storytelling as there is visual storytelling going on.  But I am hooked and the entire game is making me want to stay for more.  I like how it evolves from a simple cutscene to a more dramatical approach later on in the level after you defeat a boss and suddenly change.  The cutscenes are quite nice and they give a really remarkable approach to the story overall. [h1]Score[/h1] 8 out of 10.

[h1]Visuals[/h1] Now here is where the game is a gold mine.  And I mean Gold mine of beauty.  The animations are wonderful, the transformations are smooth and entertaining, the creature movements are fluid and well timed.  The game really looks good.  The developer could very well have worked at disney with art this nice.  I mean it is truly marvelous. All the environments look good and clean, all the backgrounds are detailed, the death animation is interesting to watch, the change of scenery is nice. I found my eye drawn to each detail.  And these are really well designed too.  Even the enemy designs are interesting. Go out and try this game and see all the art for yourself, I cannot describe just how good it all looks.  This may just get my vote for video game for the next six months.  [h1]Score[/h1] 8.7 out of 10

[h1]Sounds and music [/h1] Beautiful tracks laden with variety as you go from place to place.  Decent sound effects from monsters and swords and fireballs and the like.  But the music.  It's rich, it's melodic, it is a very good match up with the games visual performance. I'm not sure so far which level's music i like the most.  I did enjoy the desert level's musical accompaniment.  I've played games where you only get a track or two, This game has more than that. and i enjoy every minute of it. The music and sounds are really good in a headset, if you have static in your speakers, you aren't giving this game justice.  [h1]Score[/h1] 8.7 out of 10.

[h1]Overall Gameplay and final thoughts[/h1]  This game is fun.  I really got into it.  The control scheme is a little odd, you use arrow keys for moving (unless you have a controller.) and you use z to attack x to jump and such. I for inventory and D  i mean the mechanical part about that was a little weird and i was like.  Well why is the inventory keyboard key so far from the attack/jump buttons.  I mean it makes sense from the practical gameplay standpoint because a lot of games use I for inventory.  I got used to it and like i said, there's a controller support too.  I really had fun with the game, it's most certainly for the entire family.

I really had lots of fun with this game and i'm fairly sure you will too.  The whole game looks, feels and sounds good. Totally worth whatever price tag their asking for.  This is the type of game that won't disappoint you in the long run. [h1]Final Score [/h1] 8.8 out of 10

40025087.review:
[h1] What Is Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap? [/h1]

Originally released on the Master System as Wonder Boy 3, the Dragon's Trap is a remake of that game. Calling the game a remake is a bit of an insult, as the game was topped up in all aspects. As Wonder Boy (or Wonder Girl, if you so choose), you'll be cursed by a dragon which puts you in the form of "Lizard-Man" who breathes fire. 

You'll need to beat the various dragon bosses, each cursing you with a new form like "Mouse-Man" and "Pirahna-Man". Every new form comes with new exploration abilities. You'll venture to new lands (or open up areas of old ones) and acquire new gear to help you overcome the various foes you'll find in each level.


[h1] How's The Remake Portion Of The Game? [/h1]

It's no secret that old games, even really well designed old games, don't hold up well. They have expectations that have been slowly removed from gaming as a whole. Things like hidden stat values, or not explaining how various mechanics of the game work. This has all been touched up, bringing Wonder Boy III firmly into modern gaming. Examples include being able to swap your secondary items without needing to open the equipment menu.

The game also features lovingly crafted hand-drawn visuals and new, orchestrated music. However for fans of the original, these can be toggled on the fly and in any combination. Want retro music and new visuals? Go for it! A nice feature of the game is the password system. While your saves work like conventional save games, you can take your password generated by the game and plug it into the original, allowing you to continue on the old version if you should wish.


[h1] Beautiful Visuals? Stunning Music? Balanced and Accessible Gameplay? What's Not To Like? [/h1] 

The game is great, but not perfect. The difficulty is slightly above what most gamers would be used to, although that's not a bad thing. Your character momentum takes some getting used to and the game never tells you where to go next. The free-form exploration of levels means you can waste a lot of time getting back on track.

But I like to think that the journey is as important as the destination, and so I only consider this to be a minor problem.


[h1] Do you recommend Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap [/h1]

Yes. Usually I'd add who the game is and isn't for, but if you've made it this far you probably already know if this is the game for you. The Dragon's Trap has been one of my favourite games this year so far.

원작을 플레이해 본 사람이라면 추천, 그렇지 않다면 추천하지 않습니다

특히 아케이드용 원더보이 몬스터랜드만 플레이해 보고 관심을 가진 분은 주의가 필요합니다

39988520.review:
Out of all the words to best describe WonderBoy: The Dragon’s Trap, the one that comes to mind to best describe the experience is déjà vu. A feeling not necessarily related to nostalgic memories but a strangeness that cannot be explained from the clash of the familiar with the new. 

Except in my case, this feeling can be explained because I had played the original, WonderBoy 3, at an age too young to understand basic game design. Until I had recently stumbled across this game, vaguely remembering that dragon curling animation, WonderBoy 3 has always remained a mystery to my younger self.  It’s one of those early game experiences where my mind made every game appear more daunting if it wasn’t completed in a single sitting. In 2018, however, my older self can only be confused why my younger self found the original so difficult, yet the magic and awe behind WonderBoy resonates more strongly now that I can appreciate its new artistry and its many, many old flaws. 

[h1]What Wonders a Fresh Coat of Paint Can Accomplish[/h1]

Whether it’s small kindlings of nostalgia or an appreciation of classic games, The Dragon’s Trap is a game that manages to mitigate the problem of having substance over its style. It is a mechanically subpar platformer with game design stuck in the ‘80s let alone comparable to an old or new Metroidvanias. However, what makes up for its dated gameplay is how much attention to detail is given in its audio and its visuals not simply to cash-in on its nostalgia but to provide that same passion from its new creators, LizardCube. (As a side note, this may also be the best projects DotEmu has ever endorsed if you ever played one of their SNK “remakes” available on Steam.)

Art is not something I tend to critique in reviews because it’s heavily subjective in its value besides the criticisms of its composition. In the case of The Dragon’s Trap, however, it would be a grave disservice if I did not illustrate how much the visuals give it a newfound charm. In many ways, these additions are masquerading the game’s simplicity because it provides enough stimulation to fool the brain into thinking there is more going behind every corner. 

For starters, let’s talk about the in-game usage of lighting. Similar to games like Abe’s Odyssey, there is an artistic touch to the backgrounds to create more movement than what is really happening. This is evident especially in the Japanese house as the lighting will create different shadows on enemies and the player as the background shifts. Throughout the desert treks this lighting technique is used in abundance as the player scales the pyramid or goes down below into the crypts, or the dark rooms below the house enclose the player with enough light only to see enemies nearby to increase the tension compared to how bright the player and enemies appear in the retro-version. 

Second, the foreground and background movement create a more dynamic feeling to the game as objects will shift behind one another to indicate movement with the player. Pillars changing with orientation to the player; statutes following you; landmarks moving with you. These elements are not simply eye-candy as they can help players navigate levels more clearly than the original while adding to the journey, especially underwater. Another in-game benefit to the added dynamism of the game are the telegraphs in combat that apply to both players and enemies to create a smoother experience. 

Again, none of these elements excuse WonderBoy’s aging problems or make the gameplay better from its visuals alone; however, these small touches in addition with the musical adaptations ranging from jazz to rock are all additions that could have been overlooked. (One could argue the simplistic gameplay makes these smaller touches stand out more because they are meant to be distractions.) Instead, this level of artistry and polish adds a level of charm hard to get right in nostalgic callbacks and it may be the one time where the rose-tinted goggles should be packed with the game. 

[h1]What Was Timeless May Not Last Forever[/h1]

There are some who believe great gameplay can be timeless; unfortunately, The Dragon’s Trap is perhaps indicative of how not all games can withstand the test of time. The combat of a primary attack and of sub-weapons in the vein of Castlevania are adequate basics, but there is a bigger problem underlying the entire game than simplistic controls. In fact, it may be the most technically impressive feature that may interest anyone who wants to play The Dragon’s Trap, the Retro/Modern filters. 

From one moment seeing the filter at work, you can already see the problem. In order to make the entire game compatible with the Modern/Retro audio and visual filters, the level design is a one-to-one recreation from ’89. This may not seem like a big issue if you have played Halo 1 or 2 Anniversary with the same feature, but if you have tried making a level in Super Mario Maker you know Mario has made significant changes for 20+ years. Many sections of WonderBoy do feature enjoyable platforming or light Metroidvania elements, yet there are many instances—especially evident in the Retro mode—where you are walking down long hallways with enemies.

This limitation of the level-design also extends to other portions of the game. Transformations are limited to specific rooms; puzzles are untouched; areas can only be accessible in a set progression of unlocks; the original’s RPG-stat progression systems remain grindy; “secrets’ remain vague as ever; and the farming technique for gold and potions is the same solution to many difficulty spikes from the original. Previous technical issues such as the game’s hitboxes and stiffness remain apparent, but the smoother animations help mitigate it negatively affecting the controls. In short, and not to sound harsh, WonderBoy may be the greatest emulation project ever created that does its damnedest to make you forget you are essentially playing the ’89 version. 

Perhaps it was naïve to think the gameplay would be altered beyond added polish. With hundreds of other inspirations available, you would think they would innovate WonderBoy for the modern age such as Shantae’s transformations and Shovel Knight’s inspired, not recreated, nostalgia and its focus on modern retro level-design. This is why I find it difficult to praise this game as much as these other classics because it ultimately comes down to a passion project remake rather than a entirely new game. The game cannot help but feel antiquated despite how much artistry was involved to keep the charade going long enough to complete it. Afterwards, it’s hard to say whether or not that is compliment.

[h1]A Game’s a Game No Matter How Simple[/h1]

Coming back to the beginning, it’s evident that if there is anyone who would appreciate this kind of game it would have been my younger self, especially with the visual assistance for navigation. This isn’t a defense that games intended for kids should have lower standards; it’s a recommendation that this game would appeal to strangers to games or to people who enjoy eye-candy over challenge. WonderBoy offers a solid three to four hours if you take your time to explore for every little reward it offers without any incentives for replay value, yet it never feels bloated. Like a good Dr. Seuss book or a piece of a candy, a small moment of sweetness now and then can be enjoyed for what it offers rather than what you could desire.

39978315.review:
Un remake a la altura de una obra maestra atemporal. Uno de los primeros metroidvanias de la época 8 bit, una mezcla de plataformas y rpg absolutamente exquisita. 
El remake es una genialidad puediendo alternar en todo momento durante todo el juego entre los gráficos, banda sonara y efectos de sonido remasterizados u originales. Además han añadido secretos y nuevos modos de dificultad (uno de ellos, de dificultad extrema, oculto) para hacer mucho más rejugable este juego.
Muy divertido de jugar, aunque se le clasifique de Metroidvania, no opta por un diseño de niveles laberíntico, sino que en su justa medida, tras un planteamiento en principio lineal deja mucho juego al backtracking, de forma que aunque no vas a perderte ni desorientarte la sensación de exploración y de volver atrás para aprovechar nuevas habilidades que desbloquearan nuevos caminos está muy bien conseguida.
La jugabilidad a mi me encanta, unas físicas con ligeras inercias que hacen que sea muy entretenido de manejar. 
De los gráficos poco que decir, pues ya los veis en los pantallazos. Una animación 2D hecha a mano que destila cariño por todos lados. Todo ello acompañado de una banda sonora de 10. Ya lo era la original, ahora totalmente orquestrada es un 10 al cuadrado.

Et les avis négatif sur ce tire qui concerne le gameplay d'époque , pas ou plus au gout de certains , je considère ces critiques comme hors sujet , tout comme les gens qui se plaignent de la maniabilité de jeux de combat sur pc en jouant au clavier , mais là c est moi qui suis hors sujet .

39916168.review:
[h1]Воспоминания о будущем.[/h1]

Классический платформер, в новом стиле о герое превозмогающем трудности.

[h1]Плюсы : [/h1]

[b]Графика.[/b] Не так много игроков кто не играл тогда в 80-90х могут хорошо воспринимать и играть в старые игры, в новой обертке игра выглядит как хорошая инди игра, и не режет глаз. 

[b]Геймплей.[/b] После победы над каждым боссом герой будет менять облик, приобретая новые возможности, и получая доступ к новым локациям. Так что геймплей периодически меняется и не приедается.

[h1]Минусы :[/h1]

[b] Боссы.[/b] Боссы не отличаются разнообразием, каждый имеет всего 1-2 вида атаки и по сути всего 1 тактику битвы, да и дойти до босса порой куда сложнее чем его победить.

[b] Гринд.[/b] Крутые предметы в игре стоять дорого и чтобы их купить придется не слабо так гриндить по меркам игры. Что немного раздражает. 

[b] Продолжительность.[/b] Игра достаточно короткая для своей цены. Даже со всем исследование мира и покупкой всех предметов хватило 7 часов.

[h1]Вывод :[/h1] 

В целом достаточно хорошее переиздание старой игры, если бы все старые игры так переиздавали. Отлично подходить для ознакомления с жанром.

39914724.review:
¡Tiempo de revivir la edad de oro de los videojuegos con un retoque contemporáneo!

Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap es una divertida aventura de acción y plataformas side-scrolling en 2D, remake del título mítico de SEGA publicado hace poco más de un cuarto de siglo, que integra perfectamente la jugabilidad y el diseño de la era moderna con la perspicacia y el desafío de la época de antaño. En esta adaptación, desarrollada por el estudio francés Lizardcube, el jugador controla al personaje titular, Wonder Boy –o Wonder Girl, si se prefiere, indicio de la apertura y la equidad de género buscadas en la actualidad dentro de la sociedad–, quien emprende una travesía extraordinaria por la Tierra de los Monstruos para romper la maldición (su cuerpo, transformado en el de una serie de bestias con habilidades distintas) que lo aflige. Un argumento sencillo, sin tangentes, que se establece correctamente a partir de los primeros minutos de juego y que fluye de forma adecuada hasta su fin, sin muchas complicaciones. 

Visualmente, Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap es una delicia. El cuidado de las ilustraciones y las animaciones, hechas en su totalidad a mano por los desarrolladores, es impecable, dando como resultado un apartado gráfico atemporal que, sin duda alguna, soportará los embates del tiempo conforme pasen los años, a diferencia de la versión original (puede accederse a esta última en cualquier momento, con algunos ajustes sencillos). Técnicamente, el videojuego es también notable, sobre todo por la fluidez de los movimientos, el mundo semi-abierto, la respuesta de los controles, la curva de dificultad (disfrutable, pero desafiante) y el detalle de los puzzles. Incluso, sonoramente, el trabajo hecho es sobresaliente, con pistas multiinstrumentales basadas en el material de origen que, a poco, transmiten una suerte de sensación retro agradable. Quizá la única falla presente sea la duración del juego (de cinco a seis horas), afectada por el sistema de guardado en nube que facilita un poco las cosas, pero mitigada hasta cierto grado por la gama de posibilidades de re-play que ofrece: speed-run, hard core mode, perfeccionista, por mencionar algunas.

Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap es una readaptación brillante, fiel en sus ideas al material original, que permite a las nuevas generaciones de videojugadores disfrutar la fiereza y el reto presentados por los títulos de antaño, al tiempo que posibilita al público más veterano revivir la grandeza de las consolas de la edad de oro, con un retoque estético contemporáneo más que bienvenido.

Puntuación: 88/100

39902369.review: This is a really nice remaster. Keeps mechanics of the original (which had slightly "heavy" player physics - takes a bit of time to get used to) while adding wonderful graphics and soundtrack (which is almost too catchy). And you can switch between original graphics/audio and remastered ones at any point, which isn't something you see often (for technical reasons). On top of this there's modern UI and gradually unlockable "gallery" containing all sorts of things from sketches to concept art to even small videos of how music for soundtrack was performed. All in all, highly recommended.

39896437.review:
I absolutely loved this game as a child but was never able to beat it because of a few simple user interface issues that made the game unbeatable (namely not telling you that the Dragon Armour makes you immune to lava or that the Thunder Blade can break the breakable blocks). Fortunetly this game has fixed all of those problems and any others you might have had with the original.
When I discovered this remake existed I got super excited, the graphics looked absolutely stunning, the music sounded amazing and the entire game seemed to ooze with charm and style. Needless to say the trailers got my nostalgia senses overflowing. But the question is, does this game live up to my expectations?
Well I am pleased to report not only does it live up to the expectations but it shatters them as well.
The graphics are even more stunning than before and the game is a flawless remake of the original down to the location of enemies whilst fixing minor issues from the original as mentioned above. The music is so damn catchy i've had it in my head ever since buying it, and the ability to switch between retro and modern graphics and the retro and modern musics and combine them in any way you like is just the icing on the cake.
This game has rocketed it's way into my top 10 favourite games of all time, I cannot reccomend this game enough.
Buy it now, especially if you were a fan of the original!
