39881156.review: A Master System classic reborn. The Wonder Boy/Monster Land/World series has always been a personal favorite of mine. I was ecstatic for this release, and I was not disappointed. This is a wonderfully faithful HD remaster of a true video gaming original. The hand drawn visuals are gorgeous. The new score is phenomenal. And if you're some kind of monster that can't be satisfied by that, you can seamlessly toggle between the original graphics and score at the push of a button in the midst of playing. I've never seen anything like this before! The difficulty seems more balanced, but I think that's a result of the new animations lulling me into a sense of false security. Make no mistake: this is an 8-bit game in logic. No hints, no tutorials, just old fashioned trial and error. If you ever wondered where the inspiration for games like the Shantae series came from, this is exactly where to start. Just great.

39875011.review:
Long story short, this is an action platformer with metroidvania elements - made way prettier than it's predecessor. Considering little else has changed, but the graphics and music, from 20 years ago - this game deserves it's cult status. The characters (different after every boss kill) are a little awkward at first, but you get the hang of it. 

I like the Metroidvania-esque backtracking. Some of the areas you've been through have spots where only a later character can access. This usually leads to pretty solid power-ups. 

It puts action first, but exploration later. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing. The original game was definitely ahead of it's time. 

Now it sounds and looks a lot better, with hand drawn characters and backgrounds - along with specially recorded score.

It takes a lot to keep my interest for a couple hours. And so it has. One of my kids love it too.

39870491.review:
Old school gameplay design, excellently remastered. A great homage to the original game. You can even load your old save files using your old passwords! Criminally unrecognized! 

And the remastered music is made of dreamstuff and moonbeams.

39870276.review:
Ça semblait hasardeux de mettre 20 euros dans ce joli remake d’un jeu réputé court, et je suis plutôt ravie d’avoir attendu cette promo à -50% qui ramène Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap à un tarif nettement mieux adapté à sa durée de vie d'environ 6h.

Le boulot artistique abattu sur cette nouvelle version est phénoménal, tant sur le plan esthétique que musical, et pour s’en apercevoir, il suffit de switcher entre les graphs et les musiques d’origine puisque le jeu l’autorise à volonté.
Ça sent bon les animations faites à la main avec amour, les couleurs savamment choisies donnent une atmosphère superbe à chaque environnement, le design est absolument irréprochable, tout semble remis au goût du jour, et pourtant, l’œuvre originale est étonnamment respectée - au pixel près !
Chaque bloc, chaque hitbox, chaque pattern est fidèle au jeu de base, et de façon 100% vérifiable grâce (donc) à l’intégration de la version originelle consultable en temps réel.

Deux ajout notables cependant :[list]

    [*]Le premier est la possibilité de choisir entre Wonder Boy et Wonder Girl : C’est un petit détail, mais que je trouve carrément cool personnellement!

    [*]Le second est une optimisation d’ordre purement ergonomique : un raccourci assez pratique pour switcher et utiliser les armes secondaires, permettant au final de profiter des 4 boutons de façade, et donc d’utiliser tout le potentiel des manettes actuelles. Excellente initiative, car malheureusement, trop de développeurs confondent  encore "retro" et "archaïque", en utilisant seulement un ou deux boutons pour désagréablement y cumuler plusieurs fonctions.
Les 4 boutons de gâchettes trouvent également un emploi propre puisqu’ils servent à switcher  les visuels / musiques entre retro / remake, ou pour faire défiler les armes secondaires.[/list]

C’est presque dommage que le jeu ne soit pas allé plus loin dans son rafraîchissement de l’œuvre, car le gameplay vieillot conserve son aspect extrêmement rigide qui eut peut-être mérité d’être assoupli par une petite mise à jour...
Les déplacements conservent le coté légèrement flottants propre à la série des "Wonder boy", le difficulté connaît parfois de petits pics étranges, le level-design regorge de petits secrets et de recoins "bloqués" qu’on oublie, et qu’on cherche ensuite désespérément une fois qu’on a obtenu le moyen de les franchir…
Et le jeu n’épargne pas de grinder par moment, pour se payer du meilleur matos, ou faire le plein de potions… Mais ces phases de farm sont finalement assez rapides, et n’ont pas le temps de se rendre réellement fastidieuses, tant parcourir l’univers attachant & coloré du jeu s'avère plaisant.

De plus, le jeu propose 3 modes de difficulté, permettant à chacun de choisir ce qui lui sied le mieux entre exploration et challenge : très appréciable.

Au final, Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap fut certainement un monument en son temps, mais il n’est devenu aujourd’hui qu’un petit jeu classique [i]sympa[/i], dont le principal mérite est de n’avoir pas trop mal vieilli malgré ses aspects raides et antiques par moments…
Si vous faites partie de la cible "nostalgique" et que cela est suffisant pour vous, foncez - mais si vous ne connaissez pas l’original et que vous vous attendez à un "super jeu" eut égard aux standards de gameplay actuels, vous risquez quand même de trouver tout ça bien sec.

Sincèrement, il me semble que son achat ne se justifie qu’à cause de l’exceptionnelle mise à jour esthétique et sonore dont il bénéficie – de là à y mettre 20 euros, peut-être pas, mais à 10 balles, je trouve personnellement que ça le fait.

39869441.review:
It's an awesome retrogame with a very nice new look.

This is coming from someone who grew up to know the game as a kid, its always been my favorite title from the 8-bit era and I couldnt believe it when I found out someone made a remaster on steam, but the best part is that all of the mechanics that were already awesome in the game remained exactly as they were and just adding an update on graphics and music. The fact that you can switch between the new look and the original retro look is something most nostalgic fan will surely appreciate.

The game is basically exactly as it was in its original version, the only changes are the additions of 6 new secret areas were you can obtain the charm stones (which originally you obtained on chest/enemies and helped you unlock more equipement at the shops for you to be able to buy).

If you have played it before, even "hard" mode wont be too much of a trouble and you will likely reach the end in a few hours, if you havent, it will probaly take you a while longer to figure out what area to go next and practice to beat each of the dragons.

Its awesome and I cannot recommend it enough.

39867493.review:
Very fun game but more on the easy side because of the 1 dimensionality of boss patterns. The Boss battles are definitely not the shining moments of this game, but the interesting levels - sprawled out on the map - attribute to the challenge in this game. The story is near exempt of dialogue, and plotwise there isn't much development other than some vague suspicion that defeating the dragons will lift your curse and return you to human form. This game is a nice time sink to be played over and over from start to finish with a fair bit a challenge, and I reccomend this game on that alone. 

[u]Pros[/u]
[list]
[*] Solid Combat
[*] Solid Platforming
[*] Interesting use of Transforming Mechanic
[/list]

[u]Cons[/u]
[list]
[*] Virtually no story
[*] Plot is vague
[*] Boss Battles are too easy
[/list]

39859990.review:
O trabalho que fizeram na remasterização desse jogo foi lindo. Cada detalhezinho é de encher os olhos e provocar sorrisos.
É o que é: um clássico do Master System, e um recadinho de amor à era 8-bits, já que o jogo não deixa nadinha de ser o que era em 1989. Sim, essa remasterização é o mesmíssimo jogo, tanto que existe a opção de jogar com os gráficos e sons originais. E é esse o grande charme desse Wonder Boy.
Vi numas análises aqui muita gente parabenizando o trabalho que fizeram com o remaster mas não recomendando o jogo justamente por conter as mesmas """"falhas"""" de um jogo antigo. Ora, bolas, é justamente isso que faz isso aqui especial! Não é um empecilho, mas sim a verdadeira proposta disso aqui. E, diante disso, e das 6 horas de deleite enorme que passei jogando The Dragon's Trap de fio a pavio, não tenho como não recomendar. Esse jogo é um clássico 8-bit por uma razão, e se tu enxergar isso, vai conseguir achar a diversão que ele proporciona até mesmo nos dias de hoje. É um proto-metroidvania maravilhoso.
Essa foi a primeira vez que joguei um jogo da série Monster World, e o remaster já foi mais do que o suficiente pra me deixar apaixonado por ela.

For those who played the original it is a trip through memory lane. It is an exact copy, but the new style of graphics give it tons of atmosphere.

The music has also been improved in quality. The only downside on this front is that there is a section in the game with totally new music, but it is so unfitting with the rest of the game that it would have been better to modernise this part just like in the rest of the game.

However, this game is not worth a €19,99 pricetag. Afterall, the game itself is really short (finished it in 2 hours, although I did still know most of the routes). Someone who is new to this game will likely spend an hour more on it. I got it on a Steam sale for €10 and I still find it a bit high for such a short game. The added hard-mode does nothing to justify this pricetag.

39847737.review:
This should be the standard for any remaster. 

Where do I start? Man, you can almost feel the love the developers put into this. The mechanics are EXACTLY the same as the original (though if you never played this, you may find it a bit clunky, as it was back in the 90's), and they adapted the hand-drawn animations to work the same as the static sprites of the base title.

If you liked the original one, you'll love this one (also you can switch between the original version and the remake by pressing 2 buttons).

I will be looking forward to seeing this developer future projects.

It was a fun walk down memory lane, but I can't fathom paying $20 (nominal full price) for it.  Wait for a sale.

The remaster is true to the original, almost to a fault.  It's more approachable since it has autosaves instead of passwords, but man, games used to have some pretty horrid controls.  

"Mercy invulnerability" in this game bounces you around the level until you fall out of whatever enemies are touching you, but it's still pretty common to get looped into something less than fun. 39819616.review:
被埋没的经典作品！
在愿望单放了很久，本着没事下载玩玩的态度，结果第一眼画面惊呆了我，好漂亮的画风，真的是惊艳！简直无法形容，人物动作很流畅，可以和茶杯头一块称之为我心中的2017最佳游戏。

BGM出奇的好听，悠闲地小调调，一点也不让人心烦。

对了，中文简直没想到，其实这样一款游戏，对中文的需要并不大，没有太多文本需要玩家去阅读，几乎一直往关底跑就好，但是官方居然也给出了中文，并且感觉中文并不是应付差事的机翻体。可见良心。

借着这个功夫好好追溯了一下这部游戏的历史，让我感叹。据说这个系列作品诞生于30年前，真是让我意外啊。这部游戏是以世嘉Master System发行的名作游戏《Wonder Boy III: The Dragon's Trap（神奇小子III：龙之陷阱）》 为基础开发的重制版游戏，本作采用了高分辨率的HD手绘动画，视觉效果非常优秀，而如果玩家想体验原作画风，在游戏中实时按一个键就切换成8-bit画面。顺便一提连BGM也可以实现一键变换复古风格。逼格满满啊。

只能说，重置的非常出色！

线程虽然不像空洞骑士这么长，但是用心的程度绝对不比空洞骑士差。

游戏还包含可收集元素，通过游玩，可以在游戏菜单发现解锁一些原画，插图，动图还有NGM录制时拍摄的视屏，真的很不错，这对我来说应该是游戏以外的额外惊喜了。

购买原生DLC也不亏，毕竟BGM真好听啊。

只可惜官方没有出原画美术设定集的DLC，不然一块买了，这些好看的原画设定真的很让人期待，如果出了我一定买！


很多人可能一开始不习惯操作，确实有点油滑，总感觉刹不住车，需要谨慎操作，玩一会就可以得心应手了。并不难。

总的来说这在我心中是一款非常优秀的作品，麻雀虽小五脏俱全嘛。

我心中的10分之作，期待下一个作品！

39813781.review:
[h1]充满回忆的窝窝头
——小评价《Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap》[/h1]

+ 精美的手绘卡通美术
+ 传统与复刻的自由转换
+ 还算有趣的变身系统
o 制作过程与游戏流程的结合
o 过于复古的关卡设计
- 糟糕的操作手感
- 流程过短 
总评：6.2/10，《Wonder Boy》几近完美的复刻，但脱离情怀来看，这是仅是一部音乐美术出彩、其他方面略显平庸的的横板过关游戏，情怀满满，乐趣缺缺。

关于这个游戏的复杂过去，可以看一下 @药荚 大佬的评测，在本评测中不做赘述 ；https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198018485266/recommended/543260/

《Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap》的音乐与美术是非常优秀的，略带调皮的手绘卡通风格与轻松自在的配乐与游戏的简单剧情结合紧密，塑造了一个童话般的冒险世界。
在这样的世界中，玩家需要操作着勇者，穿越充满隐藏要素、风格各异的地图，打败恶龙、接受诅咒化身动物，再踏上寻找解咒之法的道路。

游戏复制了当年的作品的一切元素，无论是多层级的地图设计、简单直白的战斗模式、多变有趣的动物变身等优点，还是糟糕的滑步位移、各种卡位bug、谈不上精巧的怪物安排等缺点，都在这个游戏得到了重现。玩家可以随时按下F1，在8bit与手绘的世界间切换，体味两种不同时代的风格的异同。
开发组将游戏的在制作过程以视频的形式穿插在关卡之间，让玩家“参与”其中，算是一种变相的META，为游戏增添了一二分乐趣。

整体而言，本作《Wonder Boy》几近完美的复刻，但脱离情怀来看，这是仅是一部音乐美术出彩、其他方面略显平庸的的横板过关游戏。就像忆苦思甜饭中的青稞面窝窝头，虽然凝聚着革命精神、泛着暗器一般的凌冽光泽，但吃进嘴里，却尝不出什么味道，噎得人难以呼吸。

39792023.review:
This game is a very competent and well-done remake, so right off the bat I want to give props to the devs. Unfortunately, I can't recommend it. This game is completely faithful to the orignal, pixel-by-pixel. If you want to relive your childhood, go ahead. If you have no nostalgia for the orignal, however, you'll find they also faithfully recreated its millions of flaws.

The original was fairly ugly even compared to other games of the time, but this is one of the 2 aspects the remake actually fixes with gusto (the other being the sound design and music.) The new art is beautiful, even if the faithfulness marrs it as well by placing the same random piles of blocks everywhere the original did. Being able to switch between versions at the touch of a button is a fun gimmick, even if it is the root cause of the severe (recreated) flaws that infect every interactive aspect.

The controls are about as bad as a 2D platformer can get, with illogical momentum that has a slow acceleration but instant deacceleration, making getting in range for melee attacks a challenge unto itself. Most hits you'll take in this game will just be running right into enemies. The hitboxes themselves are extremely inaccurate and never in a way that favors the player. The difficulty spikes all the time due to the armor system where enemies will either do no damage at all or kill you in 3 hits. I'm talking about enemies in the SAME level. The awkward controls also leave almost no room to "git gud" either, so the answer is the grind out new armor sets and brute force your way through the many instances of unavoidable damage. The bosses are some of the worst I've seen in any game and the hitboxes somehow seem even worse when fighting them. They'll charge right through your blade and hit you, leading to the most baffling flaw in the game: the knockback system. Any time you're hit by an enemy, you become invincible and lose all control until you're able to land without touching any other hazard. With bosses, this always means being juggled for 10-20 seconds pointlessly. It doesn't make the game any harder, it just frustrates and wastes your time. Aside from being juggled, the bosses seem ruled by pure RNG rather than any kind of AI or pattern, and they all come down to just getting pixel-perfect timing on your (jumping) sword slash as they charge forward. This is how EVERY boss is killed.

The level design is quite imaginative and evokes a sense of wonder with its many secrets and teases, and the game's 5 playable characters are used well for opening new paths (though the controls for each of them are similarly terrible.) Unfortunately, every level goes on too long, repeating the same rooms (literally the same rooms) over and over, with the enemy patterns slightly changed. If you die (which is more random chance than skill, due to the main method of survival being random drops of resurrect potions) you get sent all the way back to town and have to trudge through 10 identical screens to return to where you were. You lose all your magic spells and return with less than full health as a bonus. Healing is also handled mostly by random drops that have no consistent spread. I've killed over 20 cyclops without a single heart drop, and had 2 full-heal hearts drop in a row elsewhere. You usually have to pay a nurse to heal up, but those aren't in many locations.

There's so much archaic design with objectively no value to be found here, like the rooms to switch animal forms where you have to linearly cycle through them and each shift takes 10 seconds. There's endless tedious backtracking even sometimes forced on the player for exploring the wrong path and being dumped back at the start. There's invisible doors required to beat the game; you just have to hold the up button on random pieces of geometry. As cool as the world was, the design flaws add up to make exploring it feel frustrating rather than wonderful.

39788822.review:
TL;DR Just start switching between modern and retro already, wtf are you reading this for

Good time to be mad at mom for throwing out those cheat sheets back in 92...

Just the fact that I can switch between retro audio and video separately AND instantly and have retro audio with modern video and vice versa is enough reason. This is how every remake for an old game should be imo, NAILED it.

Both the visuals and audio for the modern version are very well made, as well, most of the time I find myself playing with a combination of retro one, and modern the other cause the modern is not just so awesomely sewn into the original, it's also a beauty to look at

As a game itself now, and for anyone that had not played Wonder boy before, this was Zelda for us sega kids. 

With the difference that this was sidescrolling, and the devs always pushed the limits of that aspect in it's gameplay. The combat is simple, as it's time demands, but still satisfying and fun, however it's challenge lies more in the fact that level design, enemy placements and movements are intentionally putting to the test all of your skills, not just how your blade swings, timing, rhythm and spacing matter very much, and you can thank it's tight controls for that cause it would be unplayable otherwise

I like how they added the option to have a girl as well, although one of their games had a girl as a main character, this specific one never did

39780036.review:
This is a wonderful remake of a classic game in which you take control of 6 different characters in order to defeat the various dragons to undo your terrible curse.
Breathe fire as the lizard-man, crawl up walls as the mouse-man, swim through the ocean as the piranha-man, do some serious damage as the lion-man, fly as the hawk-man and do your generic semi-important things as the hu-man.
All of them are needed to explore the areas, find all the secrets (there are many!), acquire all the weapons, armor and shields, and reach parts of the world you could not explore before.
A nice touch is that you can decide to play this game in its original style, complete with soundtrack! Just hit the left or right bumpers on your controller (or the keyboard equivalent) and watch as the game switches seemlessly between retro and modern.
Highly recommended for its beautiful art style, music and challenges that are 'just right'.
If you've played the original, what are you waiting for? And if you haven't, you may want to give it a go after playing this great remake ;)

39760795.review:
So, wow, this game. First of all some positives:

The graphics and animation are awesome. They are genuinely a treat to watch. It's great!

Sound and music are equally as good.

But here's the bad:

This game is just plain bad. The controls are extremely clunky. I'm sure they are that way because it's a remake and that's what the original controls were like, but it's just bad. The hit detection is beyond broken making your attacks frustrating and specific to land.

The structure of the game is said to be "non-linear" but I didn't find it very non-linear at all. There was a clear single way to go at all times. Yes every now and again there was a branching path, but that really meant an alternat screen to go forward on.

Worst part is, the game gets worse as you go on, and it really doesn't make much sense to begin with. Every time you kill a boss the game transforms you into a less powerful and more annoying to control form. Why? I don't know. 

The game is also unforgivingly and impossibly hard for dumb reasons. Mostly due to how utterly awful the controls are.

This is just not a good game. Whoever remade it has put an extremely loving fresh coat of paint, but the core of the experience is genuinely awful.

39757230.review:
Both the art and the music in Wonder Boy: The Dragon's Trap are absolutely delightful, or dare I say... Wonderful.  Ben Fiquet did an excellent job expanding upon the inspired, stylized pixel art of the original, into beautiful backgrounds and fluid animations.  And Michael Geyre's instrumental cover compositions do a great job of staying true to the melody and feel of the original music, but also take it further where the original may have been limited by the hardware with the kind of tone that could be set.

Being able to unlock a gallery of art, and videos of the musicians recording in the studio, is a really nice touch, too.  It helps players appreciate the work that went into those aspects of the game, and is a clear indicator that the director, Omar Cornut, appreciates them, too.

But it's worth noting, that while the art and music do a masterful job of bringing Dragon's Trap into the 21st century, some of the gameplay can, at times, show its age.  There are many secrets, some of which are absolutely required for progression, and there's one, while not mandatory, that will leave you having to backtrack in the game a LOT if you miss it.  And your character will usually feel quite "heavy," though the fluid animations make it far more understandable than how frustrating it could be in the original.

Probably the biggest part of this game (a core part of the original) that could be hit or miss depending on the player, is the progression.  Kind of like an early Metroidvania, there are many sections where you cannot pass until you have a certain ability acquired elsewhere.  But unlike some more modern Metroidvanias, some of the spots can be hard to see, or can be a bit puzzling even with the right tools.  So be prepared to either rack your brain to see/remember where things are, (or to look things up).

Anyway, if you're a fan of the Wonder Boy series, or can even appreciate games from the 8-bit era, I highly recommend this game.  But if you need a game to give you clear directions on where to go at all times, you should probably give this a pass.

It's cute but what is the point of refurbishing something that I have never heard of and advertising it with things like "Feeling nostalgic yet?"? no I don't because I'm not 30+ years old and so aren't a lot of players and at this point just having pixelshit and claiming it as nostaligia is devaluing the word a bit, I suppose what I am trying to say is that if they just didn't bother with that and focused more on modernising the gameplay and presentation it would probably wouldn't have put me off so quickly.

Sure the drawings of the characters are nice and well done but this type of thing reminds me of why we don't make things like this anymore, the nonsensical world that doesn't feel like it's lived in, there are these pigs that act as vendors and nothing else as well as some animal based enemies but that's it, there are blocks that don't make sense to be there at places (because nostalgic-world design presumably) and over all there doesn't seem to be much love put into the world from the brief time I've spent in it combined with the not very free flowing gameplay it makes for a not very fun to delve in experience and for someone as admittedly picky as me that kills the thing for me which is sad because I think it's fucking cute when the lizard bites his tale when he turns into a ball when he ducks.

btw. I picked the girl because I wanted to see if the animals change sex as well but they don't so ...


Anyway, perfect segway to the Megaman esq. gimmick of form/ability-swapping between characters (or animals in this case) which is a bit of a redundant thing in the game in my opinion when you could have just had one Metroid esq. character that could do everything at once (or at least with a bit more of a gradual progression curve) you could have had it so that  you needed to figure out how to make those abilites work for your and your situation which would have made the game more interesting and challenging but alas we don't live in such a world, sunnyboy so all we actually have in this game is just some rooms with much more comparitively mundane challenges and arbitrarily blocked off areas in the overworld within a game that works with a control-scheme that opperates on the;

El chico maravilloso:la trampa del dragon es un remake
del juego clasico para megadrive lanzado a principios de
los 90.

Fue la tercera entrega de Wonderboy para sistemas
domesticos,este se caracteriza en introducir elementos
de aventura y rpg,es decir podremos equiparnos una
serie de items para que sea mas facil la aventura.

Es un juego de plataformas que combina la exploración
y la aventura otorgando un genero de juego llamado
Metroidvania pero sin llegar al extremo esa dificultad.

En esta entrega se ha añadido un nuevo personaje
llamado Wondergirl,con el que empeze la partida.

Comenzamos en una aldea con nuestro dragoncito
y tendremos que explorar las areas que estuviesen
disponibles para vencer al jefe de area y controlar
otro personaje.

Cada personaje tiene su habilidad única como por
ejemplo el ratoncito es capaz de caminar por las
paredes.

El objetivo del juego tal y como se nos muestra
al principio es derrotar al mechadragon para
pacificar la tierra de monstruos de nuevo.

Para finalizar decir que el juego cuenta con
tres ranuras para salvar la partida,es decir
podremos tener hasta tres partidas
simultaneas en mosterland.

Ah!comentar que el juego tiene tres niveles
de dificultad.

Juego recomendado para todas las edades,
ya que lo disfrutaran por igual.

Estoy con ganas de volver a introducirme
en monsterland <3.
